headline: US Issues License for Oil Companies to Operate in Venezuela
summary: The Trump administration issued a general license expanding the ability of oil companies to operate in Venezuela, marking a significant step to ease sanctions under the new US-backed leadership in Caracas.  The license issued by the US Treasury Department Thursday covers a variety of activities that could expedite the movement of Venezuelan crude, including exporting, selling, storing and refining that oil, as long as the work is performed by a US entity.  According to an administration official, it does not cover upstream crude production inside the country where currently just one US oil company ‚Äî Chevron Corp. ‚Äî operates under a special US license.

content.title: US Issues License for Oil Companies to Operate in Venezuela
content.summary: The Trump administration issued a general license expanding the ability of oil companies to operate in Venezuela, marking a significant step to ease sanctions under the new US-backed leadership in Caracas.  The license issued by the US Treasury Department Thursday covers a variety of activities that could expedite the movement of Venezuelan crude, including exporting, selling, storing and refining that oil, as long as the work is performed by a US entity.  According to an administration official, it does not cover upstream crude production inside the country where currently just one US oil company ‚Äî Chevron Corp. ‚Äî operates under a special US license.

headline: Chevron Reports Fourth Quarter 2025 Results
summary: HOUSTON, January 30, 2026--Chevron Corporation (NYSE: CVX) reported earnings of $2.8 billion ($1.39 per share - diluted) for fourth quarter 2025, compared with $3.2 billion ($1.84 per share - diluted) in fourth quarter 2024. Included in the quarter was a net loss of $128 million due to pension settlement costs. Foreign currency effects decreased earnings by $130 million. Adjusted earnings of $3.0 billion ($1.52 per share - diluted) in fourth quarter 2025 compared to adjusted earnings of $3.6 bil

content.title: Chevron Reports Fourth Quarter 2025 Results
content.summary: HOUSTON, January 30, 2026--Chevron Corporation (NYSE: CVX) reported earnings of $2.8 billion ($1.39 per share - diluted) for fourth quarter 2025, compared with $3.2 billion ($1.84 per share - diluted) in fourth quarter 2024. Included in the quarter was a net loss of $128 million due to pension settlement costs. Foreign currency effects decreased earnings by $130 million. headline: Chevron And Exxon Top Earnings But Only One Supermajor Saw Profit Growth; U.S. Oil Prices And Venezuela In Focus
summary: Chevron and Exxon Mobil both reported fourth-quarter earnings and revenue before Friday's stock market open.  Exxon Mobil notched its first quarterly profit increase in more than a year and enters Friday's stock market trading around record highs.  Exxon Mobil reported Friday that Q4 EPS increased 2.4% to $1.71, while revenue declined 1.3% to $82.31 billion.

headline: Chevron Stock Rises After Dividend Hike. Venezuela Is a Potential Distraction.
summary: Chevron  beat Wall Street‚Äôs expectations for its fourth-quarter earnings expectations and raised its dividend on Friday, a sign that the company is achieving its goal of boosting cash-flow and sending more of it to shareholders.  The biggest questions now are whether Chevron will start diverting some of that cash to drill in Venezuela, and whether shareholders will like that strategy.  Chevron‚Äôs stock was up 0.9% in early trading.

content.title: Chevron Stock Rises After Dividend Hike. Venezuela Is a Potential Distraction.
content.summary: Chevron  beat Wall Street‚Äôs expectations for its fourth-quarter earnings expectations and raised its dividend on Friday, a sign that the company is achieving its goal of boosting cash-flow and sending more of it to shareholders.  The biggest questions now are whether Chevron will start diverting some of that cash to drill in Venezuela, and whether shareholders will like that strategy.  Chevron‚Äôs stock was up 0.9% in early trading.

headline: US oil giants say it's early days on potential Venezuela boom
summary:
ExxonMobil and Chevron said Friday that they were awaiting signs of greater fiscal and legal stability in Venezuela before significantly shifting their approach to the oil-rich country.- 'Stability' -
Chevron, the only US oil company that has continued to operate in Venezuela, believes the country "has the opportunity to become a more sizable part of our portfolio in the future," said CEO Mike Wirth on an conference call with analysts.

content.title: US oil giants say it's early days on potential Venezuela boom
content.summary:
ExxonMobil and Chevron said Friday that they were awaiting signs of greater fiscal and legal stability in Venezuela before significantly shifting their approach to the oil-rich country.- 'Stability' -
Chevron, the only US oil company that has continued to operate in Venezuela, believes the country "has the opportunity to become a more sizable part of our portfolio in the future," said CEO Mike Wirth on an conference call with analysts.

thumbnail.caption: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods told President Donald Trump earlier this month that Venezuela was 'uninvestable' unless it strengthened legal protections (ALEX WONG)
